I presented the general background as had been done with
Chadeayne and Newburn, and then showed the resolution to
Jorgensen and Steetle. Jorgensencs first reaction was to ask
that we not make any requests for funds to carry out these
plans until the JCET’s current request (then before the Fund)
had been acted upon* He reminded me that we had pledged
ourselves to support the JCETfs request for a two year grant,
and that, since this undoubtedly involved some questions of
jurisdictional areas, it might jeopardize the Joint Council’s
request if we should go to the Ford Foundation or one of the
Funds with our request for this money before the JCET’s
request had been acted upon. I readily agreed to this. (As
a matter of fact, since their grant is for the period beginning
January 1, and our Foundations Committee requests for the
fiscal year under which we operate—July 1, 1958 - June 30,
1959—will not be made until some-months thereafter, theirs
is acted upon first anyway.)
Jorgensen then requested me to write him a formal letter
transmitting the resolution of the Board which he would then
distribute to the members of the JCET, for discussion at the
next meeting of the Council (or executive committee, whichever
meets first). This I since have done for both him and Newbum.
The situation was not one in which it was possible for
the JCET to formally respond to our proposal. In the first
place, this secret had been so well kept that the proposal hit
Jorgensen and Steetle without, I am sure, any previous
knowledge of it on their part; hence, they had no thought-
through reaction. In the second place. President Jorgensen,
being an experienced university administrator, would naturally
refer this to the entire Joint Council before coming up with
a reply. When It does come before the Council, I shall be in
the unique position of a member of the Council passing upon
the proposal, and also the spokesman for the organization
which makes it! This may put me In what is known colloquially
as "the hot seat!"
Insofar as I was able to guess the reactions of Jorgensen
and Steetle, as expressed and implied, I believe this proposal
will not meet with their full approval. They suggested that
this was an area in which the Joint Council had a great and
immediate interest? and, of course, it is. They suggested
that the proposal constituted an implied criticism of the way
this part of the job has been done. In fact, the resolution
expressly Indicates this? it says "No present efforts toward
this end seem to offer an immediate practical solution, or,
indeed, a long-term one."
Where do we go from here? First. 1 shall formally transmit
this proposal to Dr. ifewburh for the ETOc, EH' Br. Jorgensen-*
(with a carbon to Ralph Steetle) for the JCET.
